message: There's always http://angel.co/
oh..nice one... never knew such site exists
I was late to apply for the summer 2011 y combinator
I know they still have late application, but looking for some other ways to get funding from vc's or angel's during the summer 2011, what are some other options?
@ericflo I don't really know any angels as of now... I am kind of at the start line here.. so any guidance based on your experience would be helpful
You could always just start working on your idea, get a few angels on board that you know, and then post to angel list to fill out your round.
get things moving, things can be done really cheaply
just start anyway
start what? launch it without worrying about vc
@equinox Oh, and apply to YC even if it's late. Just filling out the app will get you thinking about your startup in new ways. Worked for me, anyway.
and in the US currently

@equinox Depends on what you're building. From what I've heard most angels will want to see a prototype at the very least. Where are you and where are you willing to go to be in a startup incubator/accelerator? There are 500 Startups, TechStars and more in cities around the US (and likely others outside the US).
yea... I think I'll apply anyways, worst case apply again for winter
I have a running prototype as of now

Angel here. Running prototype is necessary ; I don't invest unless I can see either a product or a market. Also nice to see a team. The app for YC is a great start toward what you will need anyway. Also, I only invest in my backyard, which is what most angels do. The bigger ones do bring you to their city, but that's the same thing; we take a big risk, so we want to see milestones met, evidence of progress, constant learning.
@hardaway Obligatory dumb question: where are you located?

She ( @hardaway ) is in Arizona and Half Moon Bay, CA (before you think I'm a stalker, it's here: http://stealthmode.com/about/) I'm not sure which yet she considers backyard for investments. If you want to know (and I'm transparent), I'm tracking her because of Half Moon Bay. I think it's really critical you know as much, if not more, about your angels than they know about you. Due diligence for a really powerful partnership goes both ways. Learned this last time, both in good and bad examples :-)

Yeah, I've been kind of a shut-in for awhile, since all of my customers were Federal, but now I'm trying to get more involved.  I have a couple of ideas that COULD use funding, but none that I'm ready to commit to enough to ask for it, but even if I was, I don't know anybody to ask.

Hi @hardaway I have a startup named Challengein (http://challengein.com). We've launched the product a month ago, we were in private beta since today, but with 200 users yet! We're trying to get a seed money and advisors who can help us to move to SF from Italy. Can I get in touch with you? Also if just for an advice? [meanwhile my email is claudio at challengein.com] Tnx!
@geoffclapp Thanks a ton.
@bmelton thanks... these suggestions do really help
@ccarnino my advice to you is to apply for Tech Stars, YCombinator, and the similar programs. I don't want to waste your time. Keep building. Keep getting customers.
@hardaway We're trying to create a great product every day and we'll continue!
techstars are in may, right?
Back on topic, @equinox Baltimore's "Startup City" (http://thestartupcity.com/) is a YC-like incubator, and they're accepting applications.
